item.title: Inside the Crisis at Tylenol
item.description: The CEO behind Tylenol thought he’d found a way to work with the Trump administration. Then everything went off the rails.
item.dc:creator: Peter Loftus
Alyssa Lukpat
Sara Ashley O’Brien

item.title: Walmart CEO Issues Wake-Up Call: ‘AI Is Going to Change Literally Every Job’
item.description: The country’s largest private employer says its head count will stay flat over the next three years, despite plans to grow, as AI eliminates some roles and transforms others.
item.dc:creator: Sarah Nassauer
Chip Cutter

item.title: The CEO Charged With Bringing Nissan Back From the Brink
item.description: Like Carlos Ghosn before him, Ivan Espinosa is trying to return the carmaker to profitability—and ensure it survives.
item.dc:creator: Rory Jones
Jason Douglas

item.title: Sinclair, Nexstar Will Bring Kimmel Back to Their ABC Affiliates
item.description: The broadcasters said they have had discussions with Disney and remain committed to free speech.
item.dc:creator: Joseph De Avila
Joe Flint

item.title: The TV Boss Who Kicked Kimmel Off His Stations and Started a Firestorm
item.description: Nexstar CEO Perry Sook has taken aim at “the unbridled and ubiquitous reach of Big Tech and Big Media.” Meanwhile, “Jimmy Kimmel Live!” remains blocked from the company’s ABC stations.
item.dc:creator: Joe Flint

item.title: Videogame Giant Electronic Arts Nears Roughly $50 Billion Deal to Go Private
item.description: Investors including Silver Lake are eyeing a deal that would likely be the largest leveraged buyout ever.
item.dc:creator: Lauren Thomas
Jessica Toonkel
Miriam Gottfried

item.title: U.S. Government Is Expected to Get Multibillion-Dollar Fee in TikTok Deal
item.description: The fee would be the latest example of the government getting paid for involvement in private-sector deals.
item.dc:creator: Miriam Gottfried
Amrith Ramkumar
Alex Leary

item.title: Blackstone Names New CEO of Real-Estate Megafund After Executive’s Fatal Shooting
item.description: Katie Keenan, another top female executive at the firm, will succeed Wesley LePatner as the head of Breit.
item.dc:creator: Miriam Gottfried

item.title: Jefferies Deepens Ties With Japan’s Sumitomo Mitsui
item.description: The Japanese firm’s SMBC unit plans to raise its stake in the Wall Street bank to up to 20%.
item.dc:creator: Lauren Thomas

item.title: Apollo Explores Sale of Internet Pioneer AOL
item.description: Apollo acquired AOL in 2021 as part of a deal to acquire that business and Yahoo from Verizon. A new deal could fetch around $1.5 billion.
item.dc:creator: Alexandra Bruell
Lauren Thomas

item.title: Corteva, a $50 Billion Seed-and-Pesticide Maker, Is Exploring a Breakup
item.description: A breakup of the $50 billion seed-and-pesticide maker could usher in a dealmaking wave in agriculture not seen since the first Trump administration.
item.dc:creator: Lauren Thomas
Patrick Thomas

item.title: Saks in Talks to Sell 49% of Bergdorf Goodman for About $1 Billion
item.description: The department-store operator intends to use the proceeds to pay down debt after last year’s acquisition of Neiman Marcus.
item.dc:creator: Suzanne Kapner

item.title: New Owners Plot Comeback for Tween Retailer Claire’s
item.description: The co-founders of private-equity firm Ames Watson, which has bought the chain out of bankruptcy, said they will hire more staff and upgrade ear-piercing stations.
item.dc:creator: Suzanne Kapner

media:content.media:credit: Jason Andrew for The Wall Street

item.title: Shoe Companies Warn of Price Increases as Tariff Costs Kick In
item.dc:creator: Liz Young

item.title: Big Brands Play Down Their Americanness Abroad
item.description: Coca-Cola, McDonald’s, Procter & Gamble have all launched ad campaigns stressing their local ties in Europe this year.
item.dc:creator: Bertrand Benoit

item.title: If Pepsi Wants to Win, It Has to Play Coke’s Game
item.description: Coke shed bottling and poured money into marketing. Unless Pepsi slims down, the gap between the two will continue to widen.
item.dc:creator: David Wainer

item.title: Cracker Barrel Shares Tumble After First Earnings Report Since Failed Rebranding
item.description: The CEO says the restaurant chain is listening to guests and is optimistic after the logo controversy.
item.dc:creator: Heather Haddon

item.title: CVC Capital Partners Confident in Outlook After Results Match Views
item.description: The global buyout firm’s earnings before interest, taxes, depreciation and amortization were 14% higher than the year prior, roughly in line with expectations.
item.dc:creator: Elena Vardon

item.title: Nvidia Predicts Cooler Growth After Sales Record
item.description: The world’s most valuable public company continued to capitalize on strong demand for AI computing, but its lackluster outlook stoked jitters about future demand.
item.dc:creator: Robbie Whelan

item.title: Alcon Shares Fall After Guidance Trim on U.S. Trade Tariff Hit
item.description: The Swiss eye-care giant said it expects a $100 million hit from tariffs this year.
item.dc:creator: Ian Walker

item.title: Homeowners Are Doing Small Projects but Deferring Big Ones, Home Depot Says
item.description: Home Depot said tariffs will soon start hitting some price tags even as consumers continue to hold off on larger projects because of higher interest rates and economic uncertainty.
item.dc:creator: Nicholas G. Miller
Inti Pacheco

item.title: Auto Industry Is Flashing a Warning Sign on U.S. Economy
item.description: CarMax, the biggest seller of used cars, said that sales and profit plunged in the latest quarter. Its shares closed down 20%.
item.dc:creator: Christopher Otts

item.title: Ford Courts Riskier Borrowers With Lower Rates for F-150 Pickups
item.description: The unusual end-of-quarter sales promotion addresses affordability for shoppers with weak credit profiles.
item.dc:creator: Ryan Felton

item.title: Warning Issued on Fake Air-Bag Parts That Can Explode and Kill in a Crash
item.description: U.S. safety regulators believe a Chinese manufacturer is linked to counterfeit parts that are now involved in five deaths.
item.dc:creator: Ryan Felton

item.title: Nvidia, Wayve in Talks Over $500 Million Investment in Self-Driving Car Startup
item.description: The potential investment could further expand their collaboration in autonomous vehicles.
item.dc:creator: Mauro Orru

item.title: A Cyberattack Crippled Range Rover Production. The Reboot Is Proving Tough.
item.description: Hundreds of high-end SUVs usually roll off Jaguar Land Rover’s production lines every day. This month, they have fallen silent.
item.dc:creator: Stephen Wilmot

item.title: Opinion | New Hampshire Sparks a Revolution in Electricity Supply
item.description: The state will exempt providers from utility regulation if they don’t connect to the grid.
item.dc:creator: Travis Fisher
Glen Lyons

item.title: Opinion | CNN and Comey
item.description: The network has a source at the center of the story.
item.dc:creator: James Freeman

item.title: Opinion | The Economic Cost of Trump’s Tariff Revival
item.description: America has a choice to make: Do we go back to the policies of Ronald Reagan or of Herbert Hoover?
item.dc:creator: Phil Gramm
Donald J. Boudreaux

item.title: Opinion | Candace Owens Is a Latter-Day Gnostic
item.description: Conspiracy theories about Charlie Kirk follow a first-century Christian heresy.
item.dc:creator: Josh Appel

media:content.media:text: Charlie Kirk at the University of Washington in Seattle, May 7, 2024.

item.title: Opinion | Baristas Should Sound Like Humans, Not Bots
item.description: Scripted behavioral interactions won’t provide authentic service.

item.title: Opinion | When the Left Censored Speech
item.description: Google admits that Biden officials pressed it to silence Covid critics.
item.dc:creator: The Editorial Board

item.title: Solar-Powered Cars and Trucks Are Almost Here
item.description: New, power-sipping EVs due next year are efficient enough to gain 10 to 40 miles of daily charge from the sun alone.
item.dc:creator: Christopher Mims

item.title: California Wants to Halt Oil Industry Exodus After Years of Climate Focus
item.description: Policymakers are trying to stave off a potential fuel-supply crunch while refineries look to close.
item.dc:creator: Collin Eaton
Ryan Dezember

item.title: Exxon’s New Ally in Fight With Activists: Its Own Retail Investors
item.description: Individual investors will be asked to cast their proxy votes in alignment with the company on shareholder proposals.
item.dc:creator: Collin Eaton
Lauren Thomas

item.title: OPEC Keeps Oil Demand View Unchanged as It Continues to Boost Output
item.description: The cartel held its oil-demand forecasts steady after agreeing to raise production again next month, doubling down on its strategy shift in a push for market share.
item.dc:creator: Giulia Petroni

item.title: Rushing to Meet AI’s Energy Needs: Oil-Field Servicers
item.description: The companies are shifting to supply power to data centers. They still risk their services going obsolete.
item.dc:creator: Jinjoo Lee

item.title: Boeing Clears Key Hurdle From 737 MAX Crashes
item.description: The aerospace giant is regaining some authority from regulators to perform final safety checks on jets.
item.dc:creator: Andrew Tangel
Drew FitzGerald

item.title: Lawmakers Urge FAA to Act on Fumes Leaking Into Commercial Aircraft
item.description: A bipartisan group cited risks to flight safety and the health of passengers and crew.
item.dc:creator: Benjamin Katz

media:content.media:credit: Bill Clark/CQ Roll Call/Zuma Press; Graeme Sloan/Bloomberg News

item.title: Delta Replaces Engine Units in Effort to Address Toxic-Fume Surge on Planes
item.description: Such incidents have led to brain injuries for crew and passengers, The Wall Street Journal reported earlier this month.
item.dc:creator: Benjamin Katz

item.title: Spirit Airlines Furloughing One-Third of Its Flight Attendants
item.description: The bankrupt airline plans to furlough 1,800 of its roughly 5,200 flight attendants, another effort by the carrier to slash expenses.
item.dc:creator: Alison Sider

item.title: Air Traffic Returns to Normal at Dallas-Area Airports After Outage, FAA Says
item.description: A telecom equipment outage prompted delays and hundreds of canceled flights.
item.dc:creator: Andrew Tangel
Alison Sider

item.title: How Zillow Got On Track for First Profitable Year Since 2012
item.description: The real-estate listings company has focused on boosting revenue and slowing head count growth to reach its profitability goal, its CFO said.
item.dc:creator: Mark Maurer

item.title: New Reporting Program Gives Companies a Platform to Highlight Emissions-Cutting Efforts
item.description: More than a dozen firms are piloting a way to report their carbon-reduction work to a newly formed environmental task force.
item.dc:creator: Yusuf Khan

item.title: For This Tractor Manufacturer, Tariffs Are Making Competition Even Stiffer
item.description: Agco doesn’t have enough U.S. sales to justify moving more production out of Europe, CFO says.
item.dc:creator: Mark Maurer
Bob Tita

item.title: The Chocolate Company Where Prices Change Every Three Months
item.description: Rocky Mountain Chocolate Factory is implementing a new dynamic pricing plan for its gourmet chocolates.
item.dc:creator: Jennifer Williams

item.title: New U.S. Accounting Rule to Establish How Companies Record Environmental Credits
item.description: The Financial Accounting Standards Board set new requirements, but walked back what businesses need to disclose from last year’s proposal.
item.dc:creator: Mark Maurer

item.title: Starbucks to Cut Hundreds More Corporate Jobs, Close Stores
item.description: The coffee chain is laying off about 900 employees in a turnaround bid that has involved streamlining corporate functions.
item.dc:creator: Heather Haddon

item.title: Has Your Starbucks Barista Been Acting Especially Friendly Lately? Here’s Why.
item.description: The coffee chain is looking to reverse a sales slump with new training—and lots of meaningful eye contact.
item.dc:creator: Heather Haddon

item.title: That Single-Use Coffee Cup Could Be on the Way Out
item.description: Cities and venues are looking for the best ways to get consumers to return cups instead of throwing them away.
item.dc:creator: Saabira Chaudhuri

item.title: The Grilled Chicken Chain Joining the Crispy Poultry Frenzy. Sort of.
item.description: El Pollo Loco aims to keep luring diners with its grilled chicken fare. Next year, fried tenders join the menu.
item.dc:creator: Jennifer Williams

item.title: Potbelly Sandwich Chain to Sell Itself to Convenience-Store Operator RaceTrac
item.description: The $566 million deal is expected to close this year. The companies don’t plan to “put a Potbelly in every RaceTrac.”
item.dc:creator: Owen Tucker-Smith

item.title: Bot Networks Are Helping Drag Consumer Brands Into the Culture Wars
item.description: AI tools have made coordinated attacks targeting corporations much more common, researchers say.
item.dc:creator: Patrick Coffee

item.title: Kimmel Draws More Than Six Million Viewers for His ABC Return
item.description: The comedian’s monologue also drew more than 15 million views on the “Jimmy Kimmel Live!” YouTube channel.
item.dc:creator: Joe Flint

item.title: Kimmel Makes Emotional Return to ABC With Trump Barbs, Comments on Kirk Controversy
item.description: Before the broadcast, Trump threatened ABC over its decision to allow the host back on the air.
item.dc:creator: Joe Flint
Katherine Sayre

item.title: Sinclair, Nexstar Won’t Air Jimmy Kimmel’s Late-Night Return
item.description: ​The broadcasters​ plan to replace “Jimmy Kimmel Live!”​ with news programming starting Tuesday night​, despite Disney saying​ the​ show will resume on ABC.
item.dc:creator: Joe Flint

item.title: PrizePicks Sells Majority Stake to Lottery Operator for $1.6 Billion
item.description: The deal with Allwyn International builds on sports gaming and prediction boom.
item.dc:creator: Katherine Sayre

item.title: Autonomous Truck Startup Kodiak Set to Go Public After $2.5 Billion Deal
item.description: The maker of software for self-driving vehicles is one of several companies aiming to automate long-haul trucking.
item.dc:creator: Liz Young

item.title: Global Ports Leader Sees Trade Shifting, Not Slowing
item.description: DP World’s Sultan Ahmed bin Sulayem says geopolitical upheaval and tariffs are creating new opportunities across the world.
item.dc:creator: Paul Berger

item.title: Why a Defense Startup Built a U.S. Supply Chain for Its 3-D Printer
item.description: California-based Divergent Technologies recently raised $290 million at a $2.3 billion valuation.
item.dc:creator: Liz Young

item.title: Surge of Imports Into Southern California Ends
item.description: Retailers and manufacturers pulled back on orders in August after tariffs spurred a rush of cargo into the ports of Los Angeles and Long Beach in previous months.
item.dc:creator: Paul Berger

item.title: U.S. Importers and Exporters Fret Over Port Fees on Chinese Ships
item.description: Worries come despite carriers’ saying they don’t plan to pass on the costs of levies set to take effect in October.
item.dc:creator: Paul Berger

item.title: T-Mobile Names Telecom Veteran as Next CEO
item.description: Srini Gopalan will lead the wireless carrier after five years under Mike Sievert.
item.dc:creator: Drew FitzGerald

item.title: SpaceX’s $17 Billion Deal Plunges Musk Deeper Into Wireless Market
item.description: The deal with EchoStar could help the Elon Musk-led company carve out a bigger role in the cellphone market.
item.dc:creator: Drew FitzGerald
Micah Maidenberg

item.title: Amazon’s Satellite Internet Venture Signs Up Its First Airline
item.description: JetBlue plans to use Kuiper satellite internet on 25% of its fleet, with some passengers gaining access to the service in 2027.
item.dc:creator: Micah Maidenberg

item.title: T-Mobile Adds More Subscribers Than Rivals
item.description: The carrier’s quarterly results beat Wall Street expectations, and the company raised its full-year forecast.
item.dc:creator: Patience Haggin

item.title: AT&T Adds Wireless and Home-Internet Subscribers, Accelerates Fiber Build-Out
item.description: The company raised its free cash flow forecast and said it will invest new tax savings into network infrastructure.
item.dc:creator: Patience Haggin

item.title: High Cost of H-1B Visas Changes Hiring Calculus at Startups
item.description: Some founders say they will hire more contractors overseas. Venture investors say the $100,000 fee will deter foreigners from founding startups in the U.S.
item.dc:creator: Yuliya Chernova

item.title: AI Startup Founders Tout a Winning Formula—No Booze, No Sleep, No Fun
item.description: To reach the dream of creating a trillion-dollar company, the 20-somethings flocking to San Francisco give up everything but their laptops.
item.dc:creator: Katherine Bindley
Xavier Martinez
Rebecca Picciotto

item.title: PsiQuantum Raises $1 Billion, Says Its Computer Will Be Ready in Two Years
item.description: The funding gives the quantum computing startup a valuation of $7 billion.
item.dc:creator: Isabelle Bousquette

item.title: This Startup Thinks Private Equity-Style Deals Will Kick-Start Crypto Adoption
item.description: Inversion Labs plans to acquire low-margin companies and outfit them with blockchain to turbocharge efficiency.
item.dc:creator: Marc Vartabedian

item.title: VCs Had No Time Off This Summer. Blame AI.
item.description: No summer lull, no breather on weekends and deals that can get snatched up in an evening: The metabolism of venture has been dialed even higher by fierce competition for AI startups.
item.dc:creator: Marc Vartabedian

item.title: Big Pharma Unfazed by Trump Tariffs, but Small Biotechs Face Vulnerability
item.description: Drugmakers have been bracing for levies and sought to get ahead of them with pledges to invest billions more on domestic manufacturing.
item.dc:creator: Joseph Walker

item.title: Six Flags Is Under Activist Pressure to Sell Its Real Estate
item.description: Land & Buildings Investment Management has about a 2% stake in the theme-park operator.

item.title: Name That Brand: Do You Remember These Famous Icons?
item.description: Some of the most familiar advertising icons go back to the 1800s. How many do you recognize?

item.title: Trump Takes Aim at Chip Makers With New Plan to Throttle Imports
item.description: The administration wants domestic manufacturing to match imports and would impose tariffs on those companies that don’t step up production.

item.title: Amazon Reaches $2.5 Billion Settlement Over Allegations It Misled Prime Users
item.description: The agreement requires the e-commerce giant to give money back to customers and change its subscription practices.

item.title: How Much Money Can You Make Chasing High-Yield Savings Rates?
item.description: We do the math to help you decide when it is worth moving your money for a higher return.

item.description: Money market accounts act as hybrids of checking and savings accounts.
item.dc:creator: Miranda Marquit

item.title: Heloc vs Home Equity Loan: When Are They a Good Idea?
item.description: With interest rates high, a home-equity loan or Heloc may be your best choice for cash right now
